title.rendered: New Logo, Identity, and On-air Look for Logo by Gretel

content.rendered:
Launched in 2005, Logo is an American television channel with programming focused on the lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) community. Owned by Viacom Media Networks (who also own MTV, Comedy Central, Spike, and others) Logo’s content has evolved from mostly movie and show reruns and other syndicated content to now including a significant range of original content like RuPaul’s Drag Race, Cucumber, and Banana. In their words, they “[Celebrate] one-of-a-kind personalities, unconventional stories and discovering what’s next—all through a mix of original and acquired entertainment that’s outrageous, smart, and inclusive.” Earlier this year, Logo introduced a new identity and on-air package designed by New York, NY-based Gretel.

We chose the name “Logo TV” because a logo is an identity and nothing’s more important than having your own, unique identity, and making it work for you. Your logo is your symbol, it’s what you put forward with pride, it’s who you are, and it’s what we are.

Logo FAQs

Until today I had never been curious enough as to why they named the channel Logo and I would have bet plenty of money that it was a more direct reference to the LGBT community instead of being named after an element of identity design. It’s an interesting choice and I like the concept behind it but it makes for THE worst search engine name. Try searching its logo on Google Images, “Logo logo“. Disaster.

The new design takes cues from mid-century modern design. It’s simple, sophisticated and clean. There’s still plenty of room for wit, humor and light-hearted fare, but the package feels elevated and puts the talent front and center.

Logo needed a light, nimble, flexible toolkit. Building our entire graphic recipe around just a few key ingredients allowed the Logo team to roll the package out quickly and easily. Subtle variations in the palette, type, imagery and pattern yield a diverse but unified brand.

Gretel project page

The brushed logotype is a signature. It lends a personal touch to the brand and complements the spare, mid-century inspired look of the package. The dot is always an accent, a pop of color.

Gretel project page

This is the third iteration of the Logo logo with the original version being one of the uglier TV channel logos I can think of. The second (now previous) version was a vast improvement but mostly because it wasn’t the original logo anymore. It was a decent wordmark with an interesting typographic choice but it felt pretty dry for a channel whose most popular show is helmed by 6-foot-4-inch drag queen RuPaul. The new logo is much more expressive if still not a great TV logo. The exaggerated letterforms create some strange counter shapes like that tote-bag sized space inside the “g” or all the air up there between the top of the “L” and the the rest of the letters. As a piece of lettering it’s not the most pleasant but I appreciate its energy and intention while being put to very good use in the on-air graphics.

As Gretel explains, “The reign of Queens and the celebration of all things camp has reached its saturation point” and so the identity goes in, perhaps, an unexpected direction. The on-air graphics rely on a cool set of patterns made from punctuation marks that would make killer pillows or sports jacket lining, particularly in the groovy color palettes specified. The use of House Industries’ Eames Century Modern reminds me of Comedy Central’s heavy use of a serif in their redesign, so there was a little deja vu there. The logo works in this context as it stands out from the rest of the elements but used in an almost secondary role it doesn’t jar as much as I would have expected. Overall, this is a fun, sophisticated, stylish overhaul that doesn’t rely on LGBT clichés.
